00013 //Kris: 
00014 //This value is the total maximum number of slots in a map.  
00015 //Players         20
00016 //Enemies         32
00017 //Creatures 32
00018 //Rebels          32
00019 //Civilians 32
00020 //Total                 148
00021 #define MAX_INDIVIDUALS                                                             148
00022 
00023 //Kris:  SERIALIZING INFORMATION
00024 //All maps must have:
00025 //    -MAPCREATE_STRUCT
00026 //          MAPCREATE_STRUCT.ubNumIndividuals determines how many BASIC_SOLDIERCREATE_STRUCTs there are
00027 //  -The BASIC_SOLDIERCREATE_STRUCTS are saved contiguously, but if any of them
00028 //          fDetailedPlacement set, then there is a SOLDIERCREATE_STRUCT saved immediately after.
00029 
00030 //These are the placement slots used by the editor to define where characters are in a map, what 
00031 //they are, what team they are on, personality traits, etc.  The Merc section of the editor is 
00032 //what is used to define these values.
00033 typedef struct
00034 {
00035       BOOLEAN fDetailedPlacement;               //Specialized information.  Has a counterpart containing all info.
00036       UINT16 usStartingGridNo;                        //Where the placement position is.
00037       INT8 bTeam;                                                             //The team this individual is part of.
00038       INT8 bRelativeAttributeLevel;       
00039       INT8 bRelativeEquipmentLevel;       
00040       INT8 bDirection;                                            //1 of 8 values (always mandatory)
00041       INT8 bOrders;                                                           
00042       INT8 bAttitude;                                                   
00043       INT8 bBodyType;                                                   //up to 128 body types, -1 means random
00044       INT16 sPatrolGrid[ MAXPATROLGRIDS ]; //possible locations to visit, patrol, etc.
00045       INT8 bPatrolCnt;
00046       BOOLEAN fOnRoof;
00047       UINT8 ubSoldierClass;                                       //army, administrator, elite
00048       UINT8 ubCivilianGroup;
00049       BOOLEAN fPriorityExistance;               //These slots are used first
00050       BOOLEAN fHasKeys;
00051       INT8 PADDINGSLOTS[ 14 ];
00052 } BASIC_SOLDIERCREATE_STRUCT; //50 bytes
00053 
00054 typedef struct
00055 {
00056       //Bulletproofing so static detailed placements aren't used to tactically create soldiers.
00057       //Used by editor for validation purposes.
00058       BOOLEAN                                   fStatic;  
00059       
00060       //Profile information used for special NPCs and player mercs.
00061       UINT8                                     ubProfile;
00062       BOOLEAN                                   fPlayerMerc;
00063       BOOLEAN                                   fPlayerPlan;
00064       BOOLEAN                                   fCopyProfileItemsOver;
00065

00071 
00072       // Can force a team, but needs flag set

00074       INT8                                      bBodyType;
00075 
00076       //Orders and attitude settings
00077       INT8                                      bAttitude;

00079

00096       //Inventory

00134 } SOLDIERCREATE_STRUCT;

00162 
00163 //These following functions are currently used exclusively by the editor.
00164 //Now, this will be useful for the strategic AI.
00165 //Definitions:
00166 //Soldier (s):    Currently in the game, but subject to modifications.  The editor has the capability to 
00167 //  modify soldier attributes on the fly for testing purposes.
00168 //BasicPlacement (bp):  A BASIC_SOLDIERCREATE_STRUCT that contains compact, very general, information about 
00169 //  a soldier.  The BasicPlacement is then used to generate a DetailedPlacement before creating a soldier.  
00170 //    Most of the soldiers saved in the maps will be saved in this manner.
00171 //DetailedPlacement (pp):  A SOLDIERCREATE_STRUCT ready to be passed to TacticalCreateSoldier to generate 
00172 //    and add a new soldier to the world.  The DetailedPlacement contains all of the necessary information
00173 //  to do this.  This information won't be saved in maps. In most cases, only very few attributes are static, 
00174 //  and the rest are generated at runtime.  Because of this situation, saved detailed placements must be in a 
00175 //  different format.
00176 //StaticDetailedPlacement (spp):  A hybrid version of the DetailedPlacement.  This is the information saved in 
00177 //    the map via the editor.  When loaded, this information is converted to a normal detailed placement, but 
00178 //    must also use the BasicPlacement information to complete this properly.  Once the conversion is complete, 
00179 //    the static information is lost.  This gives us complete flexibility.  The basic placements contain relative
00180 //  values that work in conjunction with the strategic AI's relative values to generate soldiers.  In no
00181 //  circumstances will static detailed placements be used outside of the editor.  Note, that this hybrid version
00182 //  uses the identical structure as detailed placements.  All non-static values are set to -1.
00183 
00184 //Used to generate a detailed placement from a basic placement.  This assumes that the detailed placement
00185 //doesn't exist, meaning there are no static attributes.  This is called when you wish to convert a basic 
00186 //placement into a detailed placement just before creating a soldier.
00187 void CreateDetailedPlacementGivenBasicPlacementInfo( SOLDIERCREATE_STRUCT *pp, BASIC_SOLDIERCREATE_STRUCT *bp );
00188 
00189 //Used exclusively by the editor when the user wishes to change a basic placement into a detailed placement.
00190 //Because the intention is to make some of the attributes static, all of the information that can be generated
00191 //are defaulted to -1.  When an attribute is made to be static, that value in replaced by the new static value.
00192 //This information is NOT compatible with TacticalCreateSoldier.  Before doing so, you must first convert the
00193 //static detailed placement to a regular detailed placement.  
00194 void CreateStaticDetailedPlacementGivenBasicPlacementInfo( SOLDIERCREATE_STRUCT *spp, BASIC_SOLDIERCREATE_STRUCT *bp );
00195 
00196 //When you are ready to generate a soldier with a static detailed placement slot, this function will generate
00197 //the proper priority placement slot given the static detailed placement and it's accompanying basic placment.
00198 //For the purposes of merc editing, the static detailed placement is preserved.
00199 void CreateDetailedPlacementGivenStaticDetailedPlacementAndBasicPlacementInfo( 
00200                SOLDIERCREATE_STRUCT *pp, SOLDIERCREATE_STRUCT *spp, BASIC_SOLDIERCREATE_STRUCT *bp );
00201 
00202 //Used to update a existing soldier's attributes with the new static detailed placement info.  This is used
00203 //by the editor upon exiting the editor into the game, to update the existing soldiers with new information.
00204 //This gives flexibility of testing mercs.  Upon entering the editor again, this call will reset all the 
00205 //mercs to their original states.
00206 void UpdateSoldierWithStaticDetailedInformation( SOLDIERTYPE *s, SOLDIERCREATE_STRUCT *spp );
00207 
00208 //In the case of setting a profile ID in order to extract a soldier from the profile array, we
00209 //also want to copy that information to the static detailed placement, for editor viewing purposes.
00210 void UpdateStaticDetailedPlacementWithProfileInformation( SOLDIERCREATE_STRUCT *spp, UINT8 ubProfile );
00211 
00212 //When the editor modifies the soldier's relative attribute level,
00213 //this function is called to update that information.
00214 void ModifySoldierAttributesWithNewRelativeLevel( SOLDIERTYPE *s, INT8 bLevel );
00215 
00216 // Force the soldier to be a different ID
00217 void ForceSoldierProfileID( SOLDIERTYPE *pSoldier, UINT8 ubProfileID );
00218 
00219 void GeneratePaletteForSoldier( SOLDIERTYPE *pSoldier, UINT8 ubSoldierClass );
00220 
00221 void QuickCreateProfileMerc( INT8 bTeam, UINT8 ubProfileID );
00222 
00223 BOOLEAN InternalTacticalRemoveSoldier( UINT16 usSoldierIndex, BOOLEAN fRemoveVehicle );
00224 
00225 //SPECIAL!  Certain events in the game can cause profiled NPCs to become enemies.  The two cases are 
00226 //adding Mike and Iggy.  We will only add one NPC in any given combat and the conditions for setting
00227 //the associated facts are done elsewhere.  The function will set the profile for the SOLDIERCREATE_STRUCT
00228 //and the rest will be handled automatically so long the ubProfile field doesn't get changed.
00229 //NOTE:  We don't want to add Mike or Iggy if this is being called from autoresolve!
00230 void OkayToUpgradeEliteToSpecialProfiledEnemy( SOLDIERCREATE_STRUCT *pp );
00231 extern BOOLEAN gfProfiledEnemyAdded; //needs to be saved (used by the above function)
